column1: kehena nʉ. Pʉetsʉ̆kŭ nʉ puhiwi maruʔi. ʉntse hipeti nikwai?
column2: No. Tomorrow I'll get money. How much do you want?
Ok. I'll give it to you.

column1: nohitsaakʉ. Nonʉ pʉetsʉ̆kŭ ʉ punin ne. ʉra.
column2: Great. I'll see you tomorrow. Thanks.
Be careful, a tornado is coming.
This is a man and this is a woman.
What can we do at the house?
indicator that the action is benefiting someone (in this case, "we")
Do you want to build a snowman?
Something good has come for us
We’re all going to find him
It is us that he loves
suffix used to refer to deceased persons
This is a good day to dance
Everyday we are learning new things.
We are praying for our Comanche people today.

column1: Nʉse nʉ nʉmʉ̠, na tsaa nabanaʔitʉ

column2: I am happy we are together
Did you put up your Christmas tree?

column1: hakarʉ se' nʉ via' tʉasʉ nʉ rami'nʉʉ
column2: who is my mother, or my brethren?

column1: soobe'sʉ nʉnʉ su nih ku puhitoo'a rʉkʉ wasʉ 'e tʉ ʉ
column2: long ago, we killed turkeys for food in that way

column1: sitʉ kʉ se' u sʉʉh po'tse nu

column2: and then it began to blow hard
and they went into a house

column1: nʉ buhiwi hta nʉ' narohtʉma kʉ nʉ rʉki 'ih a watsi kʉ'
column2: I lost my money that I had put in a can

column1: urii urii maka hka kʉ se'

stack things on top of one another
